importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Dutch government invoked the Goods Availability Act to take control of Nexperia on this date, citing serious administrative shortcomings and threats to technological security.
An emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber concluded that there may be valid reasons to doubt the sound management at Nexperia under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng.
China tightened export controls on critical rare-earth metals, citing national security, which intensified tensions with the US and Europe over semiconductor supply chains.
China’s Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.
The US Bureau of Industry and Security extended export control restrictions to groups owning 50% or more of companies on the US Entity List, including Wingtech, which was added in December 2024.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 2025 to end of 2025 reflects escalating geopolitical tensions over semiconductor supply chains, leading to regulatory actions by the US, China, and the Netherlands.

keyTakeAways: The Dutch government took effective control of Nexperia, a semiconductor manufacturer, under the Goods Availability Act due to concerns over managerial mismanagement and threats to European technological security.
Nexperia, owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology, has been under scrutiny due to its leadership under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng, who is accused of serious administrative shortcomings.
The intervention was prompted by a combination of US export controls on Chinese-owned tech firms and China's own export restrictions on rare-earth metals and components used in semiconductors.
The Dutch government blocked key corporate decisions at Nexperia, including asset relocations, executive firings, or changes to operations, for one year without approval.
Wingtech has responded by calling the Dutch intervention 'geopolitical bias' and 'unfounded,' and its shares have dropped significantly on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
The EU is coordinating with the Netherlands to protect critical technology capabilities in Europe amid growing global tensions over semiconductor supply chains and national security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch government has taken effective control of the semiconductor company Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology, under the Goods Availability Act due to serious managerial shortcomings and concerns over the continuity of critical technological capabilities in Europe. The intervention follows an emergency hearing that questioned the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng, who is accused of poor management. It also comes amid escalating geopolitical tensions, including US export controls on Chinese-owned tech firms and China’s own export restrictions on rare-earth metals and semiconductor components. The Dutch government has blocked key corporate decisions for one year and requires approval for any changes to operations. Wingtech has responded by calling the move politically motivated and biased, and shares have fallen sharply. The EU is now coordinating with the Netherlands to protect Europe’s technological autonomy in the face of global supply chain disruptions and national security fears.
title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?
